byline: By Davey Alba and Stuart A. Thompson

abstract: After marinating in conspiracy theories and Donald J. Trump’s Russia stance, some online discourse about Vladimir Putin has grown more complimentary.

abstract: The former president, who assailed Hillary Clinton in 2016 for her handling of sensitive material, was confirmed by the National Archives to have taken classified documents with him when he left office.

title: Charitable Offer by Melania Trump Is Rejected, a Move She Calls ‘Politics’
abstract: Mrs. Trump assailed what she called attempts to “cancel her” as she comes under criticism, along with her husband, for post-White House fund-raising efforts.

title: Got a Covid Booster? You Probably Won’t Need Another for a Long Time
abstract: A flurry of new studies suggests that several parts of the immune system can mount a sustained, potent response to any coronavirus variant.

title: Who Is Behind QAnon? Linguistic Detectives Find Fingerprints
abstract: Using machine learning, separate teams of computer scientists identified the same two men as likely authors of messages that fueled the viral movement.

byline: By William K. Rashbaum, Ben Protess, Jonah E. Bromwich, Kate Christobek and Nate Schweber
title: 2 Prosecutors Leading N.Y. Trump Inquiry Resign, Clouding Case’s Future
abstract: The resignations came after the Manhattan district attorney, Alvin Bragg, was said to have expressed doubts about the case.

title: The C.D.C. Isn’t Publishing Large Portions of the Covid Data It Collects
abstract: The agency has withheld critical data on boosters, hospitalizations and, until recently, wastewater analyses.

title: Melatonin Isn’t a Sleeping Pill. Here’s How to Use It.
abstract: The “vampire hormone” can act like a dose of sunset, tricking your body into feeling like it’s time to sleep.

title: Ex-Modeling Agent and Epstein Associate Found Dead in a Paris Jail
abstract: Jean-Luc Brunel had been charged with the rape of minors and was suspected of scouting young girls for Jeffrey Epstein.

title: If Joe Biden Doesn’t Change Course, This Will Be His Worst Failure
abstract: “The current humanitarian crisis could kill far more Afghans than the past 20 years of war.”

title: The Next Affordable City Is Already Too Expensive
abstract: In Spokane, Wash., home prices jumped 60 percent in the past two years. The increase is fueled by buyers fleeing the boom in cities like Austin. Who will have to flee next?

title: Two Teenagers Were Fighting. Only the Black One Was Handcuffed.
abstract: A video of the fight at a New Jersey mall circulated widely online. Gov. Philip D. Murphy said the appearance of “racially disparate treatment” was “deeply, deeply disturbing.”

byline: By Azi Paybarah and Steve Eder
title: 2 Louisiana Deputies Are Arrested and Fired After Fatal Shooting
abstract: The Jefferson Parish officers each face a count of manslaughter in the shooting of an unarmed man in a parked car, the latest in a long line of seemingly avoidable killings by the police in recent years.

title: Red Covid, an Update
abstract: The partisan gap in Covid deaths is still growing, but more slowly.

byline: By Amelia Nierenberg and Illustrations by Tim Peacock
title: Should You Still Wear a Mask?
abstract: Experts weigh in on where, and when, you can safely take one off.

title: U.S. House Candidate Apologizes for Behavior at Sleepover
abstract: Parents said Abby Broyles of Oklahoma drank and swore at children at a friend’s home. She said she had mixed wine with medication and had no memory of the night.

byline: By Steven Lee Myers and Kevin Draper
title: With Olympics Closing Ceremony, China Celebrates a Joyless Triumph
abstract: The Games ended without disaster but overshadowed by a doping scandal, rising tensions in Europe and anxiety over the future of the sporting movement.

title: Returning to Fox Business, Neil Cavuto credits vaccination with saving his life.
abstract: The veteran host had been absent from the network for more than a month while he battled a case of Covid that landed him in the I.C.U.

title: Kim Potter Sentenced to 2 Years in Prison for Killing Daunte Wright
abstract: Ms. Potter fatally shot Mr. Wright after drawing her gun instead of her Taser during a traffic stop near Minneapolis.

byline: By Ed Shanahan and Jesse McKinley
title: New York Judge Dies by Suicide After Authorities Search His Home
abstract: John Michalski, a respected trial court judge, had come under scrutiny amid a federal prosecution of a former client. He denied any impropriety.

byline: By Nicole Sperling and Matt Stevens
title: Will Smith Resigns From Academy After Slapping Chris Rock at Oscars
abstract: The producer of the telecast, Will Packer, said that Smith had been asked to leave after slapping Rock, and that he had urged officials not to “physically remove” the actor.

byline: By Malachy Browne, David Botti and Haley Willis
title: Satellite images show bodies lay in Bucha for weeks, despite Russian claims.
abstract: The images rebut Russia’s claim that the killing of civilians in Bucha, near Kyiv, took place after its soldiers had left town.

title: A Flight Over China in Clear Skies, Followed by a Nosedive
abstract: Investigators face a formidable challenge in figuring out why China Eastern Flight 5735 crashed on March 21.

title: A New Covid Mystery
abstract: Why haven’t cases started rising again in the U.S.?

title: Two More Republicans Back Jackson as Senate Moves Toward Confirmation
abstract: The support of Senators Mitt Romney and Lisa Murkowski for Judge Ketanji Brown Jackson’s nomination was a counterpoint to the bitterly partisan confirmation process so far.

title: Sarah Lawrence Cult Leader Convicted of Trafficking and Extortion
abstract: In 2010, Lawrence V. Ray moved into his daughter’s dormitory, gathered a circle of young followers around himself and began years of domination.

title: Seven Decades Later, the 1950 Census Bares Its Secrets
abstract: Federal law kept the answers on millions of census forms secret for 72 years. The forms went online on Friday, a bonanza for historians, genealogists and the merely curious.

byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs and Stacy Cowley
title: Student Loans Are Set to Be Paused Again, Pushing Payments to September
abstract: The White House is said to be planning to announce the seventh extension of the pandemic relief program, affecting tens of millions of borrowers.

title: ‘I-65 Killer’ Who Terrorized Motel Clerks in the 1980s Is Identified
abstract: The authorities said they connected Harry Edward Greenwell, who died in 2013, to at least three murders in Kentucky and Indiana, using genetic genealogy.

title: House Votes to Decriminalize Cannabis
abstract: Democrats, with some Republican support, voted 220-204 to remove marijuana from the federal list of controlled substances, moving to catch up to the states.

title: Ohio Woman Convicted of Murder in 1993 Death of Newborn
abstract: Genealogical research helped lead police to the baby’s identity nearly three decades later.

byline: By Reid J. Epstein, Patricia Mazzei and Nick Corasaniti
title: Judge Rules Parts of Florida Voting Law Are Unconstitutional
abstract: The ruling against a major Republican election law, issued by a federal judge in Tallahassee, is likely to be overturned either by a higher appeals court or the U.S. Supreme Court.

title: Putin ‘Just Threw Over the Chess Board,’ and Russians Feel Shame and Dismay
abstract: Once again, Russia has become a pariah spreading lies and death.

byline: By Eric Lipton and Maggie Haberman
title: She Took the White House Photos. Trump Moved to Take the Profit.
abstract: The former chief White House photographer made plans to publish a book of Trump photos. The former president had other plans.

byline: By Stacy Cowley and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: The student loan pause is supposed to end in a month. That looks unlikely.
abstract: Loan servicers were told to hold off on sending bills, signaling that an extension is probably in the works.

byline: By Elizabeth Dias and Ruth Graham
title: The Growing Religious Fervor in the American Right: ‘This Is a Jesus Movement’
abstract: Rituals of Christian worship have become embedded in conservative rallies, as praise music and prayer blend with political anger over vaccines and the 2020 election.

title: Zelensky blasts Merkel and Sarkozy for denying Ukraine NATO membership.
abstract: In a video address, he said that NATO’s decision in 2008 not to give Ukraine a path to membership helped lead to atrocities by Russian forces.

title: Why Are Seemingly Functional Adults Falling for the ‘Furries’ Myth?
abstract: The culture war is also a generational war.

title: Kentucky Governor Vetoes Transgender Sports Bill
abstract: The State Legislature, which is dominated by Republicans, may override the veto. Twelve states have enacted legislation barring young transgender athletes from participating in girls’ sports.

title: ‘This Was Trump Pulling a Putin’
abstract: Amid the current crisis, Fiona Hill and other former advisers are connecting President Trump’s pressure campaign on Ukraine to Jan. 6. And they’re ready to talk.

title: Spurred by Putin, Russians Turn on One Another Over the War
abstract: Citizens are denouncing one another, illustrating how the war is feeding paranoia and polarization in Russian society.

title: At the Masters, Tiger Woods Finishes, a Victory in Itself
abstract: By Sunday, the crowds that swarmed his opening rounds of the tournament had thinned somewhat. Woods finished 13 over, but the score seemed beside the point.

title: An uptick in U.S. virus cases is concerning but not surprising, Fauci says.
abstract: Dr. Anthony S. Fauci said on Sunday that the virus was still a threat, but that people needed to decide for themselves what risks to take.

byline: By Tracey Tully and Shlomo Schorr
title: Why This Coastal County Has the Highest Covid Death Rate in Its State
abstract: Ocean County, a predominantly white and middle-class community in central New Jersey, also has low vaccination rates.

title: A makeup artist recognized this Bucha victim’s picture by her manicure.
abstract: The woman, Iryna Filkina, had worked at a heating plant. She had contacted the makeup artist for help being more beautiful and fashionable.

byline: By Benjamin Weiser and Colin Moynihan
title: Cuba Gooding Jr. Pleads Guilty to Forcible Touching
abstract: The actor must complete six more months of treatment with no new arrests under his plea deal.

title: Text From Donald Trump Jr. Set Out Strategies to Fight Election Outcome
abstract: In a message two days after Election Day 2020, the president’s son conveyed a range of ideas for keeping his father in office.

title: The city of Philadelphia will reinstate an indoor mask mandate, the first major U.S. city to do so this spring.
abstract: The move comes a little more than a month after the city lifted it.

byline: By Shashank Bengali and Katrin Bennhold
title: Russians discussed killings of civilians in radio traffic intercepted by Germany, officials say.
abstract: The report adds to evidence of indiscriminate killings by Russian forces. It could not be confirmed whether the radio transmissions collected by German intelligence were from Bucha or another place near the capital, an official said.

byline: By David D. Kirkpatrick and Kate Kelly
title: Before Giving Billions to Jared Kushner, Saudi Investment Fund Had Big Doubts
abstract: Before committing $2 billion to Mr. Kushner’s fledgling firm, officials at a fund led by the Saudi crown prince questioned taking such a big risk.

title: My Advice for American Veterans Who Want to Get on a Plane to Ukraine
abstract: People there are suffering. Discouraging my fellow veterans from going there would be both hypocritical and disingenuous.

byline: By Clay Risen and Peter Keepnews
title: Gilbert Gottfried, Comedian With a Distinctive Voice, Dies at 67
abstract: His credits ranged from the family-friendly “Aladdin” to the unfettered vulgarity of “The Aristocrats” and included a brief stint on “Saturday Night Live.”

title: Help Wanted: Adjunct Professor, Must Have Doctorate. Salary: $0.
abstract: After protests, U.C.L.A. took down a job posting that offered no pay. But it turns out colleges often expect Ph.D.s to work for free.

title: In Conference Call Before Riot, a Plea to ‘Descend on the Capitol’
abstract: Days before Jan. 6, a onetime aide to Roger J. Stone Jr. told Trump backers to make lawmakers meeting to finalize the 2020 election results feel that “people are breathing down their necks.”

title: Pink Floyd says it will release its first new track in decades to support Ukraine.
abstract: The song, “Hey Hey Rise Up,” is a reworking of a protest song from World War I and features the Ukrainian rock star Andriy Khlyvnyuk of the band Boombox.

byline: By Eric Schmitt, Jane Arraf and Michael Levenson
title: Russia Shuffles Command in Ukraine as Thousands Flee the East
abstract: The Russian campaign will be consolidated under a veteran of the Syrian war, while Western nations pump additional arms into Ukraine.

title: Kidd Creole, Member of Pioneering Rap Group, Is Convicted in 2017 Killing
abstract: The founding member of Grandmaster Flash and the Furious Five, whose real name is Nathaniel Glover, was convicted of manslaughter in the death of a homeless man.

title: Putin’s War in Ukraine Shatters an Illusion in Russia
abstract: Russians long lived with an understanding: Stay away from politics, and live your life as you choose. The war in Ukraine wrecked that idea.

byline: By Benjamin Weiser and Troy Closson
title: 4 Are Charged in Overdose Death of Michael K. Williams
abstract: Security video helped investigators piece together the sale of the fatal dose to Mr. Williams, best known for his role on “The Wire,” according to court records.

title: Former Miss USA Cheslie Kryst Dies at 30
abstract: Ms. Kryst, who was also a correspondent for the television show “Extra,” was found dead on Sunday in New York.

title: Two Long Island nurses made more than $1.5 million in a fake vaccine card scheme, prosecutors say.
abstract: The nurses sold fake vaccination cards and entered false information into New York’s immunization database.

title: What We Can Learn From How the 1918 Pandemic Ended
abstract: Overconfidence, indifference and weariness are perhaps the biggest dangers.

title: Restaurants to Customers: Don’t Call Us, We Won’t Call You
abstract: When restaurants abandon their phone lines, it can make the lives of employees easier but leave diners confused and frustrated — or relieved.

title: How Do You Respond When an Anti-Vaxxer Dies of Covid?
abstract: Don’t give in to schadenfreude. It warps the soul.

title: ‘Jeopardy!’ Hasn’t Had a Player Like Amy Schneider
abstract: The most successful woman to compete on the show can finally celebrate her 40-day winning streak. And the money.

title: The Covid Vaccine We Need Now May Not Be a Shot
abstract: Nasal vaccines under development around the world may make better boosters by stopping the coronavirus in the airways.

byline: By Sharon LaFraniere and Noah Weiland
title: Pfizer is expected to ask the F.D.A. to authorize its Covid vaccine for children under 5.
abstract: Pfizer and BioNTech in mid-December announced that two doses of the vaccine, given at a tenth of the amount of an adult dosing, did not produce a strong enough immune response in children ages 2 to 4.

byline: By Alyssa Lukpat and Jesus Jiménez
title: Two Officers Killed at Bridgewater College in Virginia
abstract: A 27-year-old suspect was caught after a widespread search at the college, about 40 miles from Charlottesville, the authorities said.

byline: By Ben Shpigel, Jenny Vrentas and Kevin Draper
title: Speculation About Tom Brady’s Retirement Intensifies
abstract: An ESPN report sent observers scrambling on Saturday, but neither Brady’s agent, his team nor the N.F.L. could confirm that the Buccaneers quarterback had made a decision about his football career.

byline: By Luke Broadwater and Alan Feuer
title: Jan. 6 Committee Subpoenas Fake Trump Electors
abstract: The panel demanded information from 14 people who were part of bogus slates of electors for President Donald J. Trump, digging deeper into an aspect of his efforts to overturn the 2020 election.

title: Rachel Maddow, MSNBC’s No. 1 star, is taking a hiatus.
abstract: The anchor is expected to be off until April, leaving MSNBC with a hole in the coveted 9 p.m. weeknight time slot.

title: The New York Times Buys Wordle
abstract: The word game, released in October, has millions of daily users.

title: How Long Can I Keep Wearing the Same Respirator Mask?
abstract: With the right care, your high-performance mask can last for multiple uses.

title: Winter Storm Tears Across Three U.S. Time Zones
abstract: Forecasters warned of dangerous icing in the Mid-Atlantic and South as the Midwest dug out from a blast of snow.

title: Death of Georgia Teen Found in Gym Mat Was ‘Weird Accident,’ Sheriff Says
abstract: Eight years after Kendrick Johnson, 17, was found upside-down in a large mat in his high school gym, the Lowndes County sheriff decided to reopen the case.

title: Rafael Nadal Wins the Australian Open, His 21st Grand Slam Title
abstract: Novak Djokovic overshadowed the first Grand Slam of the year before it began, but Nadal pulled off an epic comeback over Daniil Medvedev that broke his tie with Djokovic and Roger Federer in men’s singles major career victories.

byline: By Reed Abelson and Christina Jewett
title: When Omicron Isn’t So Mild
abstract: For those with underlying medical conditions, the latest pandemic wave has still posed a threat.

title: ‘Stealth’ Variant No Cause for Alarm, but Could Slow Case Decline
abstract: A mutated version of the Omicron variant could slow the steep decline in cases, but it is not likely to change the overall course of the pandemic, scientists said.

title: Russia Is a Potemkin Superpower
abstract: The Ukraine war has revealed the Putin regime’s true weakness.

byline: By Leah Askarinam and Blake Hounshell
title: What We’re Watching in Tuesday’s Texas Primary Election
abstract: The first election night of the 2022 midterms has some famous names and crowded primary races. Here’s a rundown.

title: In State of the Union, Biden Will Focus on Economy and Global Response to Russia
abstract: The speech was originally going to center primarily on the president’s domestic agenda. But the war in Europe has forced the White House to change gears.

title: Richard Blum, Political Donor and Husband of Senator Feinstein, Dies at 86
abstract: As a financier, he amassed a fortune that he spent on Democrats, helping to propel his wife from San Francisco mayor to a long career in the Senate.

title: A few members of the Russian Parliament speak out against the war.
abstract: In a rare show of dissent, three deputies of the State Duma have expressed regret about the attack.

title: Republicans Block Abortion Rights Measure in Senate
abstract: With a Supreme Court ruling looming, both parties expect the issue to resonate in this year’s midterm elections.

byline: By Luke Broadwater, Emily Cochrane and Zolan Kanno-Youngs
title: Bracing for Biden and Protests, Officials Fortify the Capitol
abstract: A security fence, National Guard troops and more police surround the Capitol in preparation for the State of the Union address and a possible truck convoy of protesters.

title: The U.S. expels 12 Russian diplomats for spying as Ukraine dominates action at the U.N.
abstract: The move is part of a larger effort to isolate Russia diplomatically and economically since it invaded Ukraine last week.

title: Ukraine Gets $22 Million in Crypto Donations to Fight Invasion
abstract: Cryptocurrency has provided a way for investors to quickly move funds to Ukrainian fighters.

title: Why Ukrainians Believe They Can Win
abstract: Idealism has been a powerful weapon in the resistance against Russia.

byline: By Eric Lipton and Dionne Searcey
title: Chinese Company Removed as Operator of Cobalt Mine in Congo
abstract: A court has given the Congolese control of one of the world’s largest sources of cobalt while allegations against the mine’s Chinese owners are investigated.

title: They Want to Break T. Rex Into 3 Species. Other Paleontologists Aren’t Pleased.
abstract: The premise, put forth in a new paper, highlights an assortment of tensions in dinosaur paleontology, including how subjective the naming of species can be.

title: Art Briles Resigns From Grambling State
abstract: Grambling had received backlash after Briles, Baylor’s coach when leaders mishandled sexual assault accusations against players, was hired last week.

title: Disney and Warner Bros. will pause theatrical movie releases in Russia.
abstract: Affected films include “The Batman” from Warner and “Turning Red” from Disney-Pixar.

title: Viatris Agrees to Settle EpiPen Antitrust Litigation for $264 Million
abstract: The proposed settlement, which requires a judge’s approval, would resolve a legal battle that began after the company, in 2016, raised the price for two EpiPens to $608 from $100.

title: A new poll finds Americans’ fears about the virus are waning.
abstract: Americans are less worried about both catching and spreading the coronavirus than they were six months ago, as the once-surging Omicron variant recedes in the United States and in much of the world, according to a new poll by The Associated Press-NORC Center for Public Affairs Research.

title: House Passes Bill to Make Lynching a Hate Crime
abstract: Lawmakers in both parties hailed the action as historic, but a separate bill to outlaw discrimination based on a person’s natural hair failed amid Republican opposition.

title: Pop Culture Site
abstract: Lisa Senzel and Jeff Chen let the good times roll.

title: Gunman Kills His 3 Children in a Sacramento County Church
abstract: The man also fatally shot an adult before killing himself during what appeared to be a supervised visit, the authorities said.

byline: By Ken Belson and Jenny Vrentas
title: At the N.F.L. Combine, Players (and Agents) Question Its Relevance
abstract: The league’s annual talent evaluation has become prime time viewing, but disputes over protocols and the rise of other scouting forums have prompted some to call for an overhaul.

title: Cuomo’s New Approach to Restoring His Reputation: TV Ads
abstract: The former governor’s commercials push a narrative that he was driven from office by “political attacks.”

title: Your Tuesday Briefing
abstract: A bloody attack on Ukraine’s second-largest city.

title: Satellite internet terminals, sent by Elon Musk, arrive in Ukraine.
abstract: Responding to a plea by a Ukrainian official, Mr. Musk delivered an unknown number of his Starlink terminals, which offer online connection via orbiting satellites, bypassing conventional providers.

byline: By David Brooks, Gail Collins, Ross Douthat and Bret Stephens
title: ‘My Fellow Americans’: Four Times Columnists Channel Joe Biden
abstract: We will start again — and we will start now.

title: Quotation of the Day: As War Grinds Into 5th Day, Kremlin Starts Hitting Harder
abstract: Quotation of the Day for Tuesday, March 1, 2022.

title: Corrections: March 1, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Tuesday, March 1, 2022.

title: Trevor Noah Reviews Putin’s Attempt at a Soviet Reunion
abstract: If bringing back the Soviet Union is Putin’s goal, the “Daily Show” host joked, long lines are a good start.

title: Word of the Day: viscous
abstract: This word has appeared in 22 articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

title: Lit-Up Landmarks
abstract: In recent days, landmarks around the world have been lit in blue and yellow. Why? And what do you think of these displays?

title: Spelling Bee Forum
abstract: Feeling stuck on today’s puzzle? We can help.

title: Within Days, Russia’s War on Ukraine Squeezes the Global Economy
abstract: The price of energy has already shot higher, and the conflict imperils supply chains, factors that could exacerbate inflation and suppress growth.

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How a High School Debate Team Shaped Ketanji Brown Jackson’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn about President Biden’s nominee for Supreme Court justice and about the outsize influence her high school experience had on her career path.

title: Virgil Abloh’s Last Show
abstract: At Off-White, paying homage to the late designer’s work and legacy.

title: Valery Gergiev, a Putin Ally, Fired as Chief Conductor in Munich
abstract: The conductor was dismissed from the Munich Philharmonic after he refused to denounce Putin’s invasion of Ukraine. He and Anna Netrebko, the Russian diva, were also fired by the Bavarian State Opera.

title: In a Novel of the ‘New India,’ Success Has a Steep Price
abstract: “Run and Hide,” by Pankaj Mishra, follows the conflicting paths of three university classmates who join India’s elite.

title: What Does Alzheimer’s Disease Do to a Marriage?
abstract: Amy Bloom’s midlife love story was interrupted by a dreaded diagnosis. In her memoir, “In Love,” she writes about what happened next.

title: When Relationship Problems Mirror the Struggles of a Nation
abstract: In his debut novel, “Groundskeeping,” Lee Cole arranges an unlikely courtship on a college campus.

title: How a Mystery Illness Cost One Writer a Decade of Health
abstract: In “The Invisible Kingdom,” Meghan O’Rourke exposes the ways our afflictions can undermine our very sense of self.

title: When the Past Can’t Be Buried: Debut Novels Dredge Up Old Ties
abstract: New fiction of familial roots and grief, spanning Louisiana, suburban New York and Trinidad.

title: When Nations Disappear, What Happens to Nationalities?
abstract: Yoko Tawada’s novel “Scattered All Over the Earth” imagines a future in which a climate crisis has eroded borders and cultural identities.

title: Sabaa Tahir’s New Y.A. Novel Poignantly Explores the Meaning of Home
abstract: “All My Rage” is a love story, a tragedy and an infectious teenage fever dream about home when you feel you don’t fit in.

title: How Sarah Polley, Child Star and ‘Canada’s Sweetheart,’ Grew Up Way Too Fast
abstract: In her essay collection, “Run Towards the Danger,” Polley discusses her early fame, her largely unsupervised adolescence and her complicated relationships.

title: A Tour of Writing’s History Bounces From Script to Script
abstract: In “The Greatest Invention,” Silvia Ferrara offers a dizzying and entertaining tour of written language.

title: In a Debut Novel, Humans Are Scarce and Humanity Is Scarcer
abstract: “The Doloriad,” by Missouri Williams, imagines a large coterie of siblings dwelling in a bleak future.

title: An Old Tale of Sea Gods and Sacrifices Gets a Fresh, Feisty Spin
abstract: Axie Oh’s latest novel, “The Girl Who Fell Beneath the Sea,” transforms a classic Korean folk tale into an empowering fantasy story about defining your own fate.

title: I Gave Up English for Lent
abstract: I wanted to give up a precious thing whose absence would make room for something revelatory.

title: May I Disinherit My Right-Wing Daughters?
abstract: The magazine’s Ethicist columnist on when tribalism tears a family apart.

title: I’m a Parent and a Statistician. There’s a Smarter Way to Think About the Under-5 Vaccine.
abstract: We need to embrace a Bayesian approach to the child vaccine data.

title: What Is Your Obligation to a Difficult, Deceptive Parent?
abstract: In her memoir, “Never Simple,” Liz Scheier writes about life as the child of a master manipulator.

title: Do You Ever Ignore Text Messages?
abstract: Is choosing not to respond to texts, emails and other digital messages rude? Or is it sometimes necessary?

title: How to Buy a Masterpiece on a Budget
abstract: With online auctions there’s no accounting for taste — only paying a price for it.

title: How the State of the Union Became One of the Weirdest Nights in American Politics
abstract: It has all the mystery and half the charm of a slapped-together awards show.

title: ‘In Love,’ a Novelist’s Powerful Memoir About a Happy Marriage and an Assisted Suicide
abstract: In her new book, Amy Bloom writes about loving her husband and helping him to end his life after a diagnosis of Alzheimer’s.

title: ‘Once I Step Out, I Am a Queen on Mardi Gras’
abstract: For a community of Black women in New Orleans, dressing up as baby dolls is a tradition in which they’re encouraged to be free.

title: ‘I Honestly Believe It’s a Game’: Why Carjacking Is on the Rise Among Teens
abstract: The crime has made a resurgence across the country over the past two years, and many of those arrested are startlingly young.

title: These Climate Scientists Are Fed Up and Ready to Go on Strike
abstract: Evidence on global warming is piling up. Nations aren’t acting. Some researchers are asking what difference more reports will make.

abstract: A sense of menace floats long enough to make you think you’re paranoid. Sooner or later, what was feared happens. And nobody makes a secret of it.

title: Lesson of the Day: ‘How a Book Is Made: Ink, Paper and a 200,000-Pound Printer’
abstract: In this lesson, students will learn from videos, photos and text about the process of making a book. Then, they will design an explainer of that process, or research how something else gets made.

title: This Memoir About the Contradictions of Grief Plays by Its Own Rules
abstract: The novelist Kathryn Davis’s personal and time-shuffling new book, “Aurelia, Aurélia,” is about the death of her husband.

title: Why Do We Watch the Weather on TV While It Is Happening Just Outside?
abstract: The strange allure of watching someone else stand in the blizzard.

title: D.I.Y.
abstract: Are you a fan of do-it-yourself projects? What have you made or fixed this way?

title: You Are Cordially Invited to Our Wedding … on Wednesday
abstract: A new trend to come out of this year’s wedding boom: saying so long to stuffy old Saturdays and booking your big day on a weekday.

title: Takeaways From the Texas Primary Elections
abstract: Republicans’ turnout swamped Democrats’, while progressives claimed wins in the first elections of the 2022 midterms.

title: ‘By the Time You Read This, I’ll Have Killed One of Your Husbands’
abstract: In Gilly Macmillan’s new novel, “The Long Weekend,” a country holiday goes very, very wrong.

title: Looking for an Endgame in Ukraine
abstract: Three scenarios for a place where our support for the Ukrainians, our sense of our own interests and the realities of Russian power might converge.

title: Will Asian Americans Bolt From the Democratic Party?
abstract: How this question gets answered has profound political ramifications.

title: The Women of ‘The Dropout’ Want to Humanize Elizabeth Holmes
abstract: In a group interview, Elizabeth Meriwether, Amanda Seyfried and Rebecca Jarvis discuss the new Hulu series about the fall of Theranos and their efforts to reveal the woman beneath the turtleneck.

title: Mistakes Happen. In the Kitchen, That Can Be the Best Thing.
abstract: For her final column, Dorie Greenspan shares how a recipe misstep led to perfectly imperfect chocolate thumbprint cookies.

title: Raising Crosswalks to Make Deadly Intersections Safer in New York
abstract: City officials want to install 100 raised crosswalks every year as part of a larger effort to redesign dangerous intersections.

title: The Making of ‘The Trojan Horse Affair’
abstract: How a doctor-turned-journalist worked with a veteran audio reporter to create a podcast about a mysterious letter that riveted Britain.

title: Why Gravel Gardens Are Better Than They Sound
abstract: Yes, they may require 80 percent less work. But their beauty alone is reason enough to rethink the way you’re gardening now.

title: Hong Kong, Buckling Under Covid, Leaves Its Most Vulnerable in the Cold
abstract: Poor residents have been forced to choose between infecting their families or sleeping outdoors because of cramped living quarters and a lack of isolation facilities.

title: Millions for Crypto Start-Ups, No Real Names Necessary
abstract: Investors give money to pseudonymous developers. Venture capitalists back founders without learning their real names. What happens when they need to know?

title: Billionaires Clash Over the Future in a Caribbean Eden
abstract: A legal feud over a hotel in St. Barts pits development against fragile nature on this tropical Arcadia for the ultrarich. It might also signal a turning point in the hyper-development of the island.

title: 5 Minutes That Will Make You Love Wagner
abstract: Rian Johnson, Patti Smith, Alex Ross and others offer favorite highlights of a composer best known for his sprawling length.

title: I Love London Theater. But Not London Theatergoing.
abstract: While full of fine shows, a long-awaited binge was also full of stress about how loosely audiences followed rules about staying healthy in a pandemic.

title: They Came to Help Migrants. Now, Europe Has Turned on Them.
abstract: As the legal ordeal of two aid workers shows, anti-migrant attitudes in Greece and across Europe have hardened — to the point that the helpers have become political targets.

title: $3 Million Homes in Connecticut, North Carolina and Pennsylvania
abstract: A Colonial Revival house in Greenwich, a three-bedroom loft condominium in Asheville and a Gilded Age showplace in Pittsburgh.

title: Plainfield, N.J.: A Diverse City With Historic Housing
abstract: The city’s ornate Victorian homes are more affordable than those in surrounding areas. But that’s only one of the reasons that people move here.

title: The C.D.C. no longer recommends universal contact tracing.
abstract: “The updated guidance is in response to changes in the nature of the pandemic and the increasing availability of new tools to prevent transmission and mitigate illness,” the agency said.

title: The Ukraine of My Childhood Is Being Erased
abstract: Ukraine’s history is filled with waves of repression.

title: Explosive Scenes as New Zealand Police Move to End Weekslong Occupation
abstract: Fires and violence at a protest opposing vaccine mandates were a rare sight in a country known for its relative serenity and stability.

title: Remote Work Doesn’t Have to Be the ‘Mommy Track’
abstract: Despite the hand-wringing of some commentary.

byline: By Michael Barbaro, Rob Szypko, Sydney Harper, Luke Vander Ploeg, Paige Cowett, John Ketchum, Dan Powell, Marion Lozano and Chris Wood
title: How Europe Came Around on Sanctions
abstract: Will the bloc’s penalties be enough to help end Russia’s war on Ukraine?

title: How Would You Describe the State of Our Union?
abstract: President Biden delivered his first State of the Union address on Tuesday. How do you think the country is doing right now?

byline: By David Leonhardt and Ian Prasad Philbrick
title: Biden for Democracy
abstract: Ukraine took center stage at the State of the Union.

title: As oil soars, OPEC and its allies decline to offer relief.
abstract: The oil cartel known as OPEC Plus said it would continue the strategy agreed to in July, rubber-stamping a 400,000-barrel-a-day production increase for April.

title: Fitbit recalls more than one million smart watches over a burn risk.
abstract: The company, which is owned by Google, received at least 174 reports of the battery in its Ionic smart watch overheating, leading to 118 reported injuries.

byline: By James Brodribb and Jason Rider
title: Spring Looks With a Loose Fit and a Carefree Attitude
abstract: This season in men’s wear, generously tailored blazers, soft shirting and relaxed tailoring keep things laid-back.

title: Ford Splits Into Electric and Gas Divisions to Speed Up Transition
abstract: E.V. operations will focus on technology and growth while the traditional business continues to chase profits. “You can’t have people work on both at the same time,” the chief executive said.

title: Stronger Muscles in 3 Seconds a Day
abstract: Men and women who briefly contracted their arm muscles as hard as possible once daily increased their biceps strength by up to 12 percent in a month.

title: Paralympics Will Allow Russian Athletes to Compete
abstract: The International Paralympic Committee said athletes from Russia and Belarus could compete as neutrals when the Games open this week after deciding it had no legal grounds to bar them.

title: Stocks rise as Powell signals steadiness, and oil prices continue to march higher.
abstract: The rise in energy prices appeared to be tied to concerns about production limits and potential disruptions to Russian supplies.

byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Sarah Kessler, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced, Lauren Hirsch and Ephrat Livni
title: Biden Talks Business in the State of the Union
abstract: From inflation to manufacturing and technology, the president’s annual address to Congress was heavy on economic issues.

title: Weekly Accessible Learning Activities: Ukraine, Advice, Cooking Insects
abstract: Each week we spotlight five student activities created for a broad range of learners based on reporting in The New York Times.

title: Pilot Watches With a Bold, Utilitarian Aesthetic
abstract: Designed with aviators in mind, these timepieces are wearable for the earthbound as well.

title: I’m Writing From a Bunker With President Zelensky Beside Me. We Will Fight to the Last Breath.
abstract: Nothing less than our freedom — and yours — is at stake.

title: How Redistricting Could Affect California Politics
abstract: New political maps are scrambling the fates of many politicians.

title: Amelia Earhart’s Helmet Sells for $825,000
abstract: The leather aviator’s helmet she wore on record-setting flights in the 1920s sold to a big money buyer.

title: Powell Says Rates Are Headed Higher, Even as Ukraine Poses Uncertainty
abstract: Jerome Powell, the Federal Reserve chair, said he would support a quarter-point increase at the March meeting.

byline: By Sui-Lee Wee, Emily Schmall and Sameer Yasir
title: ‘We Are on Our Side’: Across Asia, a Mixed Reaction to Ukraine War
abstract: While most American allies in the region have fallen in line, authoritarian governments and those with weaker ties to the West have been more reluctant to act.

title: Who’s Afraid of Ketanji Brown Jackson?
abstract: The powerful symbolism of her nomination runs deep.

title: Set Your Schedule in Your Smartphone’s Free Calendar
abstract: As daily life feels more familiar, apps from Apple and Google can keep you organized and get you to your in-person events on time.

title: Putin’s War to Bring Ukraine to Heel Unites Eastern Europe in Alarm
abstract: Many countries fear that the Russian leader’s efforts to turn back the clock and reclaim a sphere of influence lost at the end of the Cold War could spell disaster for them.

title: Also at Stake in Ukraine: the Future of Two Orthodox Churches
abstract: The Russian church hopes to reunite with the independent Ukrainian branch under a single patriarch in Moscow that would allow it to control the holiest sites of Orthodoxy in the Slavic world.

title: At the State of the Union, Dressing for Ukrainian Solidarity
abstract: Red, white (yellow) and blue were on display as President Biden addressed Congress.

title: The State of the Union: Together, if Only for a Few Minutes
abstract: President Biden brought a cheerleading tone to a normal-ish address for very abnormal times.

title: House Hunting in Canada: Weathered Steel on the Shores of Nova Scotia
abstract: With remote workers flocking to its bucolic shores, the rapidly growing Atlantic province of Canada isn’t ‘looked at as the poor cousin anymore.’

title: Ghislaine Maxwell Juror May Be Made to Testify About His Conduct
abstract: The juror, whose failure to disclose his past abuse has clouded the guilty verdict against Ms. Maxwell, would be granted immunity from prosecution.

title: NATO Countries Pour Weapons Into Ukraine, Risking Conflict With Russia
abstract: Brussels is proud to be providing military aid, but Moscow may see it as a dangerous intervention.

title: Autofiction for People Who Think They’re Sick of It
abstract: Claire-Louise Bennett’s second novel, “Checkout 19,” centers on the passionate collision between reader, writer and book.

title: Broadway’s Cort Theater Will Have a New Name: James Earl Jones
abstract: The landmark theater will be renamed in honor of the 91-year-old actor who has made 21 Broadway appearances and won two competitive Tony Awards.

byline: By Emily Flitter and David Yaffe-Bellany
title: Senators want to know if Russia can use cryptocurrencies to skirt sanctions.
abstract: Four Democrats have asked Treasury officials to explain how they’re overseeing digital assets while Russia is largely frozen out of traditional commerce.

title: Anxiety Grows in Odessa as Russians Advance in Southern Ukraine
abstract: Residents of Odessa, Ukraine’s critical port on the Black Sea, are bracing as Russian naval and ground forces approach. “Every day they make it seem like today is the day,” the mayor said.

title: The World Is Awash in Plastic. Nations Plan a Treaty to Fix That.
abstract: The new pact would be legally binding and could go beyond cleaning up plastic waste to curbs on future production.

title: Before Invasion, Ukraine’s Lithium Wealth Was Drawing Global Attention
abstract: Chinese and Australian investors had been lining up to explore for lithium, a metal that is critical to batteries and the world’s transition to clean energy.

title: Cook to Comfort
abstract: Reader requests for borscht, crispy frico chicken and more solace-providing recipes to make very soon.

title: New Law Overhauling N.Y.’s Parole System Is Being Ignored, Lawyers Say
abstract: The so-called “Less Is More Act” took effect this week, but lawyers for dozens being detained for parole violations said in a court filing that the state corrections department was disregarding parts of it.

byline: By Thomas Gibbons-Neff, Christina Goldbaum and Najim Rahim
title: Taliban Search Operation Echoes Resented U.S. Tactics
abstract: An intrusive sweep that has spanned several provinces risks alienating Afghans and fueling the insurgency the new government is trying to stop.

byline: By Erin Woo and Kevin Roose
title: This Social Club Runs on Crypto Tokens and Vibes
abstract: Friends With Benefits is a V.I.P. lounge for crypto’s creative class. Is it empty hype or the future of friendship?

title: Twitter Wants to Reinvent Itself, by Merging the Old With the New
abstract: The company is undertaking a far-reaching effort to change how it works. For some, it is an echo of their early idealism and a vision for what the internet could have been.

title: NoViolet Bulawayo Believes Freedom Begins With Imagination

title: Shirley Hughes, Whose Books Depicted Children’s Mini-Dramas, Dies at 94
abstract: Beloved in her native England, she wrote and illustrated more than 70 books for children of all ages, with millions of copies sold worldwide. She was honored by the queen.

byline: By Jan Ransom and William K. Rashbaum

abstract: The season saw more farewells, from principals Teresa Reichlen and Gonzalo Garcia, along with a rush of talent from the recently promoted.

title: Venezuela’s Leader Trades Old Guard for Slick Technocrats to Keep Power

title: A Conductor Brings Nearly a Century of Experience to Beethoven
abstract: Herbert Blomstedt, 94 and leading the New York Philharmonic this week, discusses the famous opening of the Fifth Symphony.

title: Biden’s Fed Nominees Are Frozen as One Faces Republican Questions
abstract: Sarah Bloom Raskin, his choice for the Federal Reserve’s head of bank oversight, has faced staunch G.O.P. opposition over her climate views. Yet her private sector work is holding up her nomination.

abstract: The league will not administer the test, which has been criticized for racial bias, to draft prospects at this year’s scouting combine. Instead, teams are deploying other assessments of football acumen.

byline: By Monika Pronczuk and Dan Bilefsky
title: The E.U. is expected to grant blanket protection to Ukrainian refugees.
abstract: Under the measure, which would apply to all Ukrainian nationals, refugees would be granted the right to live, study and work across the 27-member bloc for up to three years.

title: ‘Hell Is Empty’ Review: Sins of the Father
abstract: In this bare-bones horror film, a young woman joins a cult and eventually defies its patriarch.

title: Barry Bauman, Restoration Artist and Detective, Dies at 73
abstract: A noted conservator, he peeled back paintings’ hidden layers and sometimes uncovered fakes, most notably a portrait wrongly thought to be of Mary Todd Lincoln.

title: Star-Studded Lakers Are Fighting Just to Make the Playoffs
abstract: LeBron James is defiant, but the fans are booing, and the season might be lost.

title: Stop-Start Schooling
abstract: The hidden costs of Omicron’s classroom closures.

byline: By Dmitriy Khavin, David Botti and Ainara Tiefenthäler
title: Mayor in Ukraine asks his city’s residents whether they wish to fight or surrender.
abstract: The mayor of Konotop, in northeastern Ukraine, said Russian soldiers had told him they would “raze the city to the ground with their artillery.”

abstract: The Russian conductor Valery Gergiev and the diva Anna Netrebko have lost engagements because of their ties to Putin, as geopolitics and music collide once again.

abstract: Brett Hankison is on trial over charges that he endangered Ms. Taylor’s neighbors. His bullets did not strike anyone, and he testified that he had done nothing wrong in the fatal police raid.

title: Bong Joon Ho and Ryusuke Hamaguchi on Oscar Surprise ‘Drive My Car’
abstract: The Korean filmmaker and the Japanese director have long admired each other. The two explain why Hamaguchi’s best-picture nominee resonates.

title: Review: A Los Angeles Troupe in Search of Choreographic Vision
abstract: Bodytraffic’s program at the Joyce Theater leaves you contemplating some problems of contemporary dance.

title: Should Tech Stay or Go in Russia?
abstract: Tech companies seem eager to support Ukraine, but how best to do that isn’t as clear.

title: Different Views of Biden’s State of the Union Address
abstract: Contrasting reactions to the president’s remarks about Ukraine. Also: Russians and Russian Americans; the Swiss freeze of Russian assets; transgender kids.

title: Reimagining Art, One Threesome at a Time

title: Insect Trash Could Be a Farmer’s Treasure
abstract: Insect feces and exoskeletons can make agriculture more sustainable and produce less waste, scientists say.

title: Dua Lipa Brings Her Lockdown Anthems to the Arena
abstract: The pop star’s second album, “Future Nostalgia,” is ambitious and impressive. Onstage, the production didn’t match the LP’s ecstasy.

byline: By Steve Eder and Ben Protess
title: Trump Hotel Chief, Hired With Big Ambitions, Leaves a Shrinking Brand

byline: By Edward Wong and Julian E. Barnes
title: China Asked Russia to Delay Ukraine War Until After Olympics, U.S. Officials Say
abstract: A Western intelligence report indicates that Chinese officials had some level of direct knowledge about President Vladimir V. Putin’s war plans or intentions.

title: Schools Chancellor Pledges to End New York City’s ‘Betrayal’ of Students
abstract: David Banks vowed in his first major policy address since becoming chancellor to break up bureaucracy, improve literacy and emphasize wellness in schools.

title: The head of a popular brewery in Brooklyn resigns after his attacks on vaccine mandates drew criticism.
abstract: Josh Stylman, a founder of Threes Brewing who called vaccine mandates “crimes against humanity,” said he was leaving so he could speak his mind freely.

title: H&M halts sales in Russia after the invasion of Ukraine.
abstract: The announcement followed similar decisions from tech companies, oil giants and Hollywood studios.

title: Gaming Giant Behind Fortnite Buys Bandcamp, an Indie Music Haven
abstract: Epic Games is acquiring an online music platform that has been embraced by musicians for its eclectic offerings and a payment system that favors artists.

title: Renowned Conductor, Battling Brain Cancer, Steps Down From Orchestra

byline: By Andrew E. Kramer and Lynsey Addario
title: 15,000 Are Sheltering in Kyiv’s Subway
abstract: People sleep three or four to a mattress and plastic food bags litter the scene, while mothers search endlessly on their phones for news of the war.

title: Amazon plans to shut down more than 50 brick-and-mortar stores.
abstract: The closures affect its bookstores and Amazon 4-Star locations, but not Whole Foods or Amazon Fresh.

title: Will Cutting Out Dairy Give Me Clear Skin?
abstract: Maybe, experts say, but the science is mixed.

title: Your Thursday Briefing: Russia Seizes Kherson
abstract: A strategically important city falls.

title: In Symbolic Vote, Senate Rejects Vaccine Mandate for Health Workers
abstract: Republicans forced the vote even though the measure has no chance of enactment, as part of an election-year effort to use pandemic precautions as a political weapon against Democrats.

byline: By Somini Sengupta and Lisa Friedman
title: War Abroad and Politics at Home Push U.S. Climate Action Aside
abstract: Climate change, a central part of Biden’s agenda, was barely mentioned in the State of the Union. And Europe is confronting its heavy reliance on Russian gas.

title: Remember Going Out? These Perfumes Promise to Take You Back
abstract: A rundown of scents, with common notes of tobacco and leather, inspired by famous nightclubs and jostling bodies.

title: Modern Love Podcast: You May Think You Know Your Parents
abstract: That is, until you have a startling revelation about them in adulthood.

title: Phil Mickelson’s Setbacks Keep Coming, and Tiger Woods Gets a Bonus

abstract: Some employees who back unionization efforts have been told they must increase their work availability or leave. The company cites scheduling issues.

title: A coalition of state attorneys general opens an investigation into TikTok.
abstract: The group is looking into the Chinese-owned video site for the harms it may pose to younger users.

title: The U.N. General Assembly passes a resolution strongly condemning Russia’s invasion.
abstract: The four-page document calls for an immediate halt to the conflict, urges diplomatic negotiations for a peaceful resolution and says Russia’s territorial gain through force will not be recognized.

title: The U.S. extends technology restrictions to Belarus and the Russian oil industry.
abstract: The Biden administration said the measures would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia.

title: Reports of civilian casualties rise in Ukraine, but exact counts remain uncertain.
abstract: As is often the case in war zones, tolls diverged. It was not immediately possible for The New York Times to provide an independent estimate.

title: Gold Ingots From 18th-Century Shipwreck Returned to France
abstract: The Chinese ingots, illegally harvested from a French frigate that sank while returning from Nanjing, were seized by U.S. investigators when they were put up for auction in California.

abstract: Her career there lasted only three days; attacked by mobs, she was suspended and then expelled. Today, a campus building is named in her honor.

title: Putin No Longer Seems Like a Master of Disinformation
abstract: The impression is one of clownish flat-footedness.

byline: By Ed Shanahan and Ali Watkins
title: N.Y.P.D. Sergeant Pleads Guilty to Assault Charges in Violent Arrests
abstract: Sgt. Phillip Wong punched one handcuffed man after being spit at and knelt on another who had taunted him with anti-Asian slurs.

title: Robert Hicks, Blockbuster Author and Battlefield Savior, Dies at 71
abstract: He published “The Widow of the South” to promote his real passion: reclaiming a Tennessee Civil War site’s complicated history.

title: Powerful Ex-Illinois House Speaker Is Indicted on Federal Charges
abstract: Michael J. Madigan, who for decades steered Democratic politics in Illinois, was charged with racketeering and accused of using his office for personal gain.

title: Man Charged With Hate Crimes After 7 Asian Women Are Attacked in 2 Hours
abstract: The women were attacked in a spree of violence in Manhattan on Sunday. A guard at the library where the man was arrested said he had been a frequent visitor.

title: As New York Students Shed Masks, Elation Mixes With Trepidation
abstract: On the first day for some school districts to go maskless, there was disagreement at one Long Island school over whether the change came too soon or was overdue.

title: Diverse Artists to Write and Illustrate New Dr. Seuss-Inspired Books
abstract: Each of the new books will be inspired by an unpublished sketch by Dr. Seuss, whose whimsical imagery has drawn new scrutiny since his estate pulled six titles from circulation last year.

byline: By Ivan Nechepurenko and Anton Troianovski
title: A War the Kremlin Tried to Disguise Becomes a Hard Reality for Russians
abstract: Moscow posted a death toll from its attack on Ukraine for the first time, and Russians who long avoided politics are now grappling with the fact that their country is fighting a deadly conflict.

title: Prosecutors Open Arguments Against Defendant in First Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: Guy Reffitt recorded himself as he entered the Capitol with zip ties and a pistol. “We’re taking the Capitol before the day is over, ripping them out by their hair,” he said.

byline: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Thomas L. Friedman, Ross Douthat and Yara Bayoumy
title: Four Times Opinion Writers on War in Ukraine: ‘It Is Very Clear Putin Has No Plan B’
abstract: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Thomas Friedman, Ross Douthat and Yara Bayoumy discuss what could come next in Ukraine.

title: ‘Against the Ice’ Review: Snow Buddies
abstract: A hard-core first half is deflated by sleepy melodrama and a formulaic script in this adventure film about the Danish explorer Ejnar Mikkelsen.

byline: By Graham Bowley and Matt Stevens
title: Vladimir Potanin, Russian Oligarch, Steps Down as Guggenheim Trustee
abstract: Mr. Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a Guggenheim Museum donor for decades, is the latest oligarch affected by widening outrage over the war in Ukraine.

title: Biden’s Plan for a New Normal
abstract: Addressing the virus while living with it.

title: French Female Directors Continue Hot Streak at Rendez-Vous Festival
abstract: The series returns in-person with an especially strong slate of work by Frenchwomen — fitting, given their run of honors at top festivals.

title: Putin Is Brandishing the Nuclear Option. How Serious Is the Threat?
abstract: The Russian president has ordered his nuclear forces into a higher state of alert — the first time the Kremlin has done so since 1991.

title: Your Wednesday Evening Briefing
abstract: Here’s what you need to know at the end of the day.

title: High-speed trains departing Russia for Finland are packed.
abstract: Once starved for passengers, the trains are now full, and negotiations are underway between state-owned Finnish and Russian rail companies to increase the service.

title: ‘The Long Walk’ Review: A Ghostly Future in Laos
abstract: This Laotian drama from Mattie Do presents a world where spirits linger on into a future that has been shaped by technology.

title: Jets’ Rebuilding Plans Do Not Include Extended Combine Stay
abstract: Coach Robert Saleh said Jets assistants and scouts would bypass the first days of the combine. The team’s G.M. said it would entertain trades involving its nine picks in the 2022 N.F.L. draft.

title: Justice Dept. Announces Task Force to Go After Russian Oligarchs
abstract: The task force adds to the raft of actions that Western leaders have taken in recent days in an effort to undercut Vladimir V. Putin and the politically connected elite in Russia.

title: Russia Captures Its First City
abstract: The fall of Kherson came as Russian forces advanced in the south.

title: How the Coronavirus Steals the Sense of Smell
abstract: The virus does not infect nerve cells that detect odors, researchers have found. Instead, it attacks nearby supporting cells.

byline: By Michael Schwirtz and Richard Pérez-Peña
title: First Ukraine City Falls as Russia Strikes More Civilian Targets
abstract: Russian forces seized the southern city of Kherson and besieged other cities, with casualties and destruction mounting, as Western sanctions tightened their vise grip on Russia’s economy.

title: Magritte Sets Record With $79.7 Million Sale at Sotheby’s
abstract: “L’empire des lumières” (1961), one of a series by the Surrealist, was auctioned during a bustling London art week.

title: M.L.B. Canceled Games. What Happens Now?
abstract: Both sides left Florida frustrated, and no one knows when the season may start. This could take a while.

byline: By Michael S. Schmidt and Julian E. Barnes
title: Biden Rehires National Security Staff Member Pushed Out Under Trump
abstract: The National Security Council confirmed that Ellen Knight, who told of improper pressure from Trump administration officials, was returning to help manage classified information.

byline: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Why Americans Might Not Rally Around Biden Over Ukraine
abstract: The days when voters put their partisan differences aside during a national security crisis appear to be over.

title: Biden’s New Covid Plan: Preparing for New Variants and Avoiding Shutdowns
abstract: The strategy is supposed to help the nation transition to what some are calling a “new normal,” but it will require funding from Congress.

title: Judge Jackson Begins Making Her Own Case for High Court Seat
abstract: Democrats hope meeting the nominee will persuade some Republicans senators to support her historic nomination to the Supreme Court.

title: Ex-Officer in Colorado Pleads Guilty to Assaulting Woman With Dementia
abstract: Austin Hopp pleaded guilty on Wednesday to second-degree assault strangulation in the case of Karen Garner, whom he pinned down during an arrest on suspicion of shoplifting from a Walmart.

title: The Young Progressive Lawyer at the Center of a Marquee Texas Runoff
abstract: Jessica Cisneros had the backing of national progressive leaders, a cramped campaign headquarters and the help of her father. She’s now taking on Representative Henry Cuellar in a runoff in May.

title: Philadelphia drops its mask mandate.
abstract: As the Omicron wave continues to subside, a growing number of cities and states are relaxing their pandemic restrictions.

byline: By Zolan Kanno-Youngs, Jonathan Weisman and Emily Cochrane
title: As Biden Pivots, Democrats Seek to Salvage His Domestic Agenda
abstract: The president repackaged his sweeping domestic policy plan with more centrist language, but it remained unclear whether Congress would resurrect key elements of his agenda.

title: Corrections: March 3, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Thursday, March 3, 2022.

title: Texas Court Halts Investigation of Parents Over Care for Transgender Youth
abstract: One family was affected by the decision, but Gov. Greg Abbott’s order to investigate certain medically accepted treatments as child abuse is still in place.

title: A Virginia senator reveals he has long Covid and unveils a bill devoted to the illness.
abstract: In an interview with The Washington Post, Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia described feeling as if his nerves have been jolted with five cups of coffee.

title: REI Workers in New York Vote to Unionize
abstract: The 88-to-14 result at a Manhattan store creates the first union at the prominent outdoor equipment and apparel retailer.

title: JetBlue Pilot, Suspected of Being Drunk, Is Removed From Cockpit in Buffalo
abstract: A T.S.A. officer noticed that the pilot “may have been impaired,” the authorities said. His blood alcohol content was found to be four times the limit for pilots.

title: Open Letter to President Biden From a Dispirited Black Voter
abstract: Representation and inclusion are important to me, but they are no substitute for policy and legislation.

title: ‘Fiat Lux’ vs. ‘Lux et Veritas’
abstract: August Lee-Kovach has his second crossword puzzle published in The New York Times.

title: Mother of Children Killed by Their Father Said She Lived in Fear
abstract: The woman obtained a restraining order in 2021 after telling a California court, “He has not killed me because he would not know where to go with the children.”

title: A Second Amazon Site on Staten Island Will Have a Union Election
abstract: The National Labor Relations Board approved the voting at a warehouse next to JFK8, where another election is in progress.

title: Nissan Ex-Executive Gets Suspended Sentence in Carlos Ghosn Case

Covid patients lose this sense even without a stuffy nose; the loss can make food taste like cardboard and coffee smell noxious, occasionally persisting after other symptoms have resolved.

title: ‘It’s Not About Me’: Scherzer Bucks a System That Worked for Him

title: U.S. Grants Temporary Protected Status to Some Ukrainians
abstract: The designation gives Ukrainians who were in the United States without legal documentation as of March 1 permission to stay and work for 18 months.

title: Ken Duberstein, a Former Reagan Chief of Staff, Dies at 77
abstract: He helped revive the Reagan presidency in its last years and became a respected lobbyist in Washington.

title: Los Angeles County is lifting its indoor mask mandate.
abstract: Los Angeles County is lifting nearly all of its indoor mask and vaccine verification requirements, local officials said.

title: Alan Ladd Jr., Hitmaking Film Executive, Dies at 84
abstract: When other studios didn’t want it, he took on the project that became “Star Wars.” He later guided “Chariots of Fire,” “Young Frankenstein” and numerous other movies.

title: ‘Traitors Get Shot’: Son Testifies Against Father in Jan. 6 Trial
abstract: Guy Reffitt’s 19-year-old son took the stand against him in federal court in a remarkable tableau that captured how one family was split by the attack on the Capitol.

title: Tech Offers a Silver Lining in Ukraine
abstract: Big Tech has shown it can make meaningful choices about who can use its platforms.

title: In Greene and Boebert, Democrats See a Helpful Political Target
abstract: The antics of Representatives Marjorie Taylor Greene and Lauren Boebert, as well as recent stumbles by other Republicans, have drawn unflattering attention to their party.

byline: By David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Julian E. Barnes
title: Washington’s Newest Worry: The Dangers of Cornering Putin
abstract: Surprised by the speed at which sanctions have been poured on Russia, Biden’s top aides suspect that Putin’s reaction will be to double down and lash out — and perhaps expand the war.

title: Need Help in a Hospital? Call a Patient Advocate.
abstract: Most hospitals have designated problem solvers on staff, but many people don’t know how to find them.

abstract: Inspired by Sophocles’ “Philoctetes,” Aleshea Harris uses poetic language, songs and symbolism to explore the trauma of being alive, especially for Black people.

byline: By Katie Benner and Charlie Savage
title: Pressure on Justice Dept. as Jan. 6 Panel Lays Out Case Against Trump
abstract: Building a criminal case against the former president is very difficult for federal prosecutors, experts say, underlining the dilemma confronting the agency.

abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 4, 2022.

byline: By Evan Hill and Dmitriy Khavin
title: Videos show scenes from one occupied Ukrainian city.

byline: By Mike Ives, William J. Broad, Malachy Browne, Brenna Smith and Ang Li
title: A fire breaks out at a nuclear plant during a Russian assault, Ukraine says.
abstract: Security camera footage showed a building ablaze inside the complex amid fighting. The fire was later extinguished. A Ukrainian agency said that Russian forces had taken control of the site.

byline: By Henry Louis Gates Jr. and Andrew S. Curran
title: We Need a New Language for Talking About Race
abstract: In the 18th century, “scientific” myths about race sought to divide people into separate groups. Today, new DNA science is revealing just how connected we really are.

byline: By Ed Shanahan and Benjamin Weiser
title: Ex-Fox News Producer Broke Law With Work for Russian Oligarch, U.S. Says
abstract: John Hanick was on Konstantin Malofeev’s payroll after Mr. Malofeev’s backing of Crimean separatists led to sanctions, an indictment says.

byline: By Patricia Mazzei and Alexandra Glorioso
title: Florida Lawmakers Vote to Ban Abortions After 15 Weeks

title: Catch up on the latest news on Ukraine.

There had been worries that the fire could spread to nuclear reactors and lead to radiation leaks, but international monitors said Friday morning that there was no immediate sign that radiation had leaked during the battle for the plant.

abstract: Readers respond to recent issues of the Sunday Book Review.

abstract: Are you good at recognizing emotions in yourself and others?

title: Remote work is changing how climbing the career ladder works.
abstract: Remote work is often favored by established employees who know their manager, are comfortable in their role and want to balance work with family responsibilities or other personal obligations. For those just starting their careers, working in isolation can make fitting into an organization — and eventually progressing up its ranks — more difficult.

abstract: WASHINGTON — The Biden administration can no longer use a public health rule to justify expelling migrant families who cross the border without documentation if doing so would subject them to persecution or torture, according to a federal appeals panel ruling issued on Friday.

abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

byline: By Norimitsu Onishi and Aurelien Breeden
title: Riding High in the Polls, an Aloof Macron Steps Into the Election Fray
abstract: The Ukraine war has given the French leader a strong edge and few reasons to engage with his political opponents. He held a news conference to quell criticism that he is avoiding debate.

title: This Cauliflower Shawarma Reaches for Spring
abstract: A vegetarian take on the Middle Eastern dish, this recipe straddles the seasons.

title: Film Club: ‘Under His Misspell’
abstract: Has your inner critic ever gotten in the way of relationships?

title: The Avant-Garde Filmmaker Who Tried to Tell the Truth
abstract: An innovative retrospective of work by Jonas Mekas reveals the fundamental honesty of his “diary” films.

title: With a Fourth World Cup Overall Title, Mikaela Shiffrin Is Back on Top
abstract: The skier said she was “embarrassed” by failing to win a medal in any of her five Beijing Olympic events. Turns out she was in it for the yearlong haul.

title: ‘Jane by Charlotte’ Review: A Mother-Daughter Duet
abstract: Charlotte Gainsbourg makes her directorial debut with an elusive portrait of her mother, the French-English star Jane Birkin, at age 74.

title: Peru’s Top Court Reinstates Pardon for Former President Alberto Fujimori
abstract: The court issued a ruling to release Mr. Fujimori from prison, where he has served less than 15 years of a 25-year sentence for committing human rights abuses. The government said it would appeal the ruling.

title: N.L.R.B. sues Amazon over labor practices at a Staten Island facility.
abstract: The labor agency wants a federal judge to order changes there in the case of a fired worker before a union election starts next week.

title: 8 New Books We Recommend This Week
abstract: Suggested reading from critics and editors at The New York Times.

title: Drought in U.S. Is Expected to Persist, and Spread, Through the Spring
abstract: Winter precipitation amounts were not enough to significantly improve conditions in much of the country, government scientists said.

title: How Much Watching Time Do You Have This Weekend?
abstract: Our TV critic’s recommendations this week include a pirate comedy, a Jane Austen drama and an Australian newsroom show set in 1986.

title: ‘The Life’ Review: Turning More Than a Few New Tricks
abstract: Billy Porter brings a heavy-handed touch as the director and adapter of this 1997 musical about prostitutes and pimps in Manhattan’s bad old days.

title: House Votes to Suspend Normal Trade Relations With Russia
abstract: The bill, which still needs Senate approval, is the latest in a series of measures that lawmakers have passed to support Ukraine and punish Russia for its invasion.

title: Citigroup will pay travel costs for employee abortions in response to the Texas law.
abstract: Citigroup is the first major U.S. bank to announce a policy change in response to the legislation, which bans abortions after six weeks of pregnancy.

title: The Art of Making Thai Noodles, Far From Thailand
abstract: Cooks in the nation’s diaspora offer wisdom on making pad Thai and other classics at home. First tip: Sometimes taste is more important than tradition.

title: Gig Workers Say High Gas Prices May Be a Breaking Point
abstract: Some drivers say they find it hard to justify spending hours on the road for Uber or Lyft as fuel costs continue to tick upward.

title: Eugene N. Parker, 94, Dies; Predicted the Existence of Solar Wind
abstract: At first, almost no one believed his findings on gigantic eruptions from the sun. Today, a NASA mission to fly through its outer atmosphere is named after him.

title: Louisiana Student Recorded Whipping Black Classmate Is Charged With Hate Crime
abstract: The 15-year-old, who also appeared to throw cotton balls at the classmate in a video, was arrested on Tuesday in connection with the episode, which “appears to be racially motivated.”

title: A Show About European Identity Opens With a Backdrop of War
abstract: Jasmina Cibic’s new exhibition explores the theatricality of nation building in Europe. She didn’t expect it to have such immediate contemporary relevance.

title: The Irish Found Their Luck in the Ivy League
abstract: Losing last year’s season to the pandemic, and other Ivy League rules, led to an exodus of talent. One of those players, Paul Atkinson, hit a game-winning shot for Notre Dame in the N.C.A.A. tournament.

title: Your Friday Briefing: The Destruction of Ukraine
abstract: Plus South Korea’s new approach to the virus and Cambodia’s crackdown on opposition leaders.

title: Koch Industries will continue to operate its factories in Russia.
abstract: Koch employs about 600 people in Russia through a unit that makes up a small part of its overall business.

byline: By Luis Ferré-Sadurní, Grace Ashford and Jonah E. Bromwich
title: Push for More Restrictive Bail Law Gains a Key Ally: Gov. Hochul
abstract: Ms. Hochul wants to expand the list of crimes eligible for bail in New York, and give judges the power to consider the danger a defendant poses in setting bail for certain crimes.

title: With Its Future Uncertain, the Humana Festival Will Not Return in 2022
abstract: The showcase of work by contemporary American playwrights will not take place this year, either in person or online — and after that, it’s up in the air.

title: What Has Been Lost in Kharkiv
abstract: Russian forces are destroying Ukraine’s second-largest city.

title: Republicans Once Silent on Russia Ratchet Up Attacks on Biden
abstract: Even as they praise the bipartisan congressional response to Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, Republicans are increasingly eager to blame President Biden for the devastation.

title: A Gender Revolution Is Brewing in New Zealand Rugby
abstract: One in five rugby players in New Zealand are now women, and their numbers are rising. But persistent stereotypes are proving hard to dismantle.

title: USAA is fined $140 million for bad money laundering controls.
abstract: Regulators say the bank, which mainly serves U.S. military members, failed to keep track of its customers’ suspicious activities despite repeated warnings that it needed to improve.

byline: By Julia Jacobs and Robert Chiarito
title: The Jussie Smollett Case Is Probably Far From Over, Analysts Say
abstract: The Illinois appellate court that ordered Mr. Smollett’s release from jail often takes months, even years, to rule on cases, according to experts.

byline: By Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Michelle Goldberg, Bret Stephens and David Brooks
title: Four Opinion Writers on the War: ‘Putin’s Final Cards Are Very Far From Played’
abstract: Lulu Garcia-Navarro, Michelle Goldberg, Bret Stephens and David Brooks discuss the latest developments in Russia’s Ukraine war.

byline: By Andrew E. Kramer, Michael Schwirtz and Eric Nagourney
title: Survivors Emerge From a Bombed Theater, but Ukraine’s Suffering Grows
abstract: Russia continues to devastate cities and hit civilians, as Ukrainian forces strike back and peace talks drag on.

title: Lia Thomas Wins an N.C.A.A. Swimming Title
abstract: With her victory in Atlanta, Thomas, who competes for the University of Pennsylvania, became the first openly transgender woman to win an N.C.A.A. swimming championship.

title: One Pizza at a Time, He Defined the New York Slice
abstract: Domenico DeMarco, who founded Di Fara Pizza in 1965, has died. He was a link between the cooking of Southern Italy and the city’s corner-slice culture.

title: Italy is planning to roll back many of its vaccine requirements.
abstract: Italy, where coronavirus cases are again on the rise, is preparing to roll back many of its vaccine requirements, Roberto Speranza, its health minister, announced on Thursday.

title: With a Flurry of High-Profile Coronavirus Cases, Washington Is Again on Edge
abstract: The cases have raised questions about the trajectory of the pandemic, even as the White House has signaled confidence about resuming normal activities.

title: Why Vladimir Putin Invokes Nazis to Justify His Invasion of Ukraine
abstract: The language of Russia’s invasion has been dominated by the word “Nazi” — a puzzling assertion about a country whose leader is Jewish.

title: Another Dictator Is Having a Bad Year
abstract: Covid is becoming China’s equivalent of Ukraine.

title: Yuri Milner’s Russian Clapback
abstract: A Russian-born tech titan takes a bold stance against his birth country’s pummeling of Ukraine.

title: This Is Why Autocracies Fail
abstract: Over the long term, centralized power is a recipe for stagnation.

byline: By Blake Hounshell and Leah Askarinam
title: Climate Activists Flex Their Political Muscle
abstract: Environmental groups want Democrats to confront oil companies over high gas prices. And Democrats are listening.

title: U.S. Will Punish China if It Gives Military Aid to Russia, Blinken Says
abstract: President Biden plans to talk on Friday with Xi Jinping, who has a close partnership with Vladimir V. Putin and supports him in the Ukraine war.

title: Video Appears to Show Death of California Man Held Down by Police
abstract: “I can’t breathe,” Edward Bronstein yelled as highway patrol officers pinned him down after a traffic stop in Burbank in March 2020, a video released this week shows.

title: Sanctions against Russia may cost BNY Mellon $200 million this year.
abstract: BNY Mellon has ceased new business in Russia and has “suspended investment management purchases of Russian securities,” it said.

title: By Labeling Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ Biden Personalizes the Conflict
abstract: President Biden’s visceral reaction to the horrifying images coming out of Ukraine also reflects a broader effort to isolate the Russian leader.

title: U.S. Calls Putin a ‘War Criminal,’ but Consequences Are Unclear
abstract: A day after President Biden’s remark, Secretary of State Antony Blinken said he agreed. Experts warned of hurdles to a successful prosecution.

title: Interrupted, Again: Suleika Jaouad on Cancer and Healing the Second Time Around
abstract: The popular writer of the “Life, Interrupted” column shares an update on her health and discusses how creativity and connection help her cope with life’s challenges.

title: National Book Critics Circle Names 2021 Award Winners
abstract: Honorée Fanonne Jeffers, Clint Smith, Rebecca Donner and Anthony Veasna So were among the winners.

title: Hoping to Identify Cheaters, a Professor Sues His Own Students
abstract: David Berkovitz, who teaches business law at Chapman University in Orange, Calif., sued an unnamed group of his students — identified only as “Does” — after he discovered that his midterm and final exams had been uploaded to a popular website.

title: Moderna asks the F.D.A. for authorization for a second booster for all adults.
abstract: The request is significantly broader than one from Pfizer, which sought another shot only for adults age 65 and older.

title: Six Killed in Chain-Reaction Crash on Missouri Interstate
abstract: The collisions resulted in a pileup of more than a hundred vehicles and closed the highway in both directions, the authorities said.

title: Clear Indication
abstract: Claire Rimkus and Brooke Husic offer us a lively Friday puzzle.

title: Variety: Cryptic Crossword
abstract: Emily Cox and Henry Rathvon’s puzzle puts us on cloud nine.

title: Mark Meadows’s 2020 Vote Is Under Investigation in North Carolina
abstract: Records show that Mr. Meadows cast an absentee ballot from the address of a remote mobile home, but reports have cast doubt on whether he lived there.

title: Kids, Covid Isolation and Learning to Endure
abstract: The virus found us, and we’re doing just fine. I think.

title: Brittney Griner Said to Be ‘OK’ as Russian Court Extends Her Detention
abstract: Griner, the W.N.B.A. star, has been detained on drug charges in Russia since mid-February and is now expected to remain in custody until at least May.

abstract: Kevin Rustagi was used to taking dates up in a plane or on a motorcycle. But to meet Katelyn Yeary, he arrived on crutches.

title: Even the Army Couldn’t Keep Them Apart
abstract: Rabbi Michael Geoffrey Cohen had 10 months left on his military contract when he met Sharon Leona Poczter. But after a marathon first date, they never fully parted.

title: On (Not) Wasting My Time With a Younger Man
abstract: We had no future together, so why not fall completely in love?

byline: By Billy Witz, Alanis Thames, Alan Blinder and Scott Miller
title: N.C.A.A. Men’s Tournament: Purdue Looks Sharp in Its Opening Game
abstract: Yale’s attempts to slow down the Boilermakers’ offense proved futile. In other first-round games, Illinois and Miami won in thrillers and Duke got past Cal State Fullerton.

title: Running Stars Are Racing in New York City, and It’s Not the Marathon
abstract: The New York City Half Marathon is scheduled to be run on Sunday for the first time in three years, and a number of prominent names will be at the starting line.

byline: By Remy Tumin, Alan Blinder and Natalie Weiner
title: N.C.A.A. Women’s Tournament: South Carolina Is Still Quite Dominant
abstract: The top-seeded Gamecocks led 44-4 at halftime and finished just as strongly. Florida Gulf Coast, a big upset pick, beat Virginia Tech.
