abstract: The department is trying out four-legged robots to use in dangerous places. “These robots will save lives,” a fire captain said.

title: Your Friday Briefing
abstract: Casualties in the war in Ukraine.

title: Corrections: March 18, 2022
abstract: Corrections that appeared in print on Friday, March 18, 2022.

title: Quotation of the Day: Robot Dogs Join New York Fire Department, Which Promises a Short Leash
abstract: Quotation of the Day for: Friday, March 18, 2022.

abstract: A Kremlin spokesman pointed the finger back at the U.S. for World War II bombings, and Trevor Noah joked, “Keep up with the times, yo!”

title: Word of the Day: fecundity
abstract: This word has appeared in eight articles on NYTimes.com in the past year. Can you use it in a sentence?

byline: By Jack Ewing and Stephen Gandel
title: How the War in Ukraine Could Slow the Sales of Electric Cars
abstract: The price of nickel, an essential ingredient in most batteries, has soared because of fear that Russian supplies could be cut off.

title: ‘Windfall’ Review: Money Talks
abstract: A wealthy couple is detained by an incompetent thief in this airless Netflix drama.

title: How Useful Is It to Be Multilingual?
abstract: Do you speak multiple languages? Are you learning a new one? How has that knowledge expanded your world?

title: New in Paperback: ‘The Copenhagen Trilogy,’ ‘Tom Stoppard: A Life’ and More
abstract: Six new paperbacks to check out this week.

title: Listening and Clapping
abstract: What do you know or think you know about this image and where it is from?

byline: By Erica Ackerberg and Natalie Proulx
title: Lesson of the Day: ‘Why Do We Change the Clocks, Anyway?’
abstract: The Senate recently passed legislation that would make daylight saving time permanent. In this lesson, students will look at the history of this ritual and decide if they support the bill.

abstract: In a conversation that carries a glimmer of hope, the foreign policy scholar Emma Ashford considers possible paths to de-escalation.

byline: By Jon Chase and Rachel Cericola
title: How to Make Your Second Home Smarter, Safer and More Sustainable

abstract: The “Tomás Saraceno: Particular Matter(s)” exhibition at the Shed — particularly the “Free the Air” installation — is drawing social media attention.

abstract: Sabeena Ladha is the founder of Deux, a raw cookie dough that is vegan and gluten-free.

title: Why Omicron Is So Deadly in Hong Kong
abstract: Low vaccination rates among the elderly have created a perfect storm.

title: Cities Move to Sever ‘Sister City’ Ties With Russian Governments

title: Once Motorcade Pals, Congressman and Photographer Are Now Public Foes
abstract: Pete Souza, the former White House photographer-turned-Trump troll, now uses his popular Twitter feed almost exclusively to ridicule Representative Ronny Jackson, the former White House doctor-turned-Trump acolyte.

byline: By Catrin Einhorn and Lisa Friedman
title: Nations Should Conserve Fuel as Global Energy Crisis Looms, Agency Warns
abstract: The International Energy Agency said countries should encourage use of mass transit and car pooling, among other things. That could also help the climate crisis.

title: The Secret Is Out on This ‘Bridgerton’ Star
abstract: A few years ago, Nicola Coughlan was working in an optician’s office in Ireland. Now, with “Bridgerton” and “Derry Girls,” she’s starring in two of the most beloved shows on Netflix.

title: Why America Should Not Deepen Its Military Involvement in Ukraine
abstract: Any direct conflict between the United States and Russia could make this humanitarian crisis much worse.

title: 6 Things We’ll Keep From Pandemic Life
abstract: Masks when we’re sick, bikes for everyone, and new respect for workers.

title: Hidden Tampa: The Best of an Often-Overlooked Florida City
abstract: From a Buddhist temple reached by boat to a storied hotel and a speakeasy bar: a cheat sheet on what to do in this Gulf Coast city, which has found new fans during the pandemic.

abstract: Fanny Herrero, the creator of “Call My Agent!,” returns with a Netflix show called “Standing Up,” which follows four struggling Parisian comics.

abstract: The Institute for Art and Olfaction celebrates a decade of exploring our sense of smell.

abstract: The artist, who probed the depths of psychic trauma, left behind elusive new portraits that will debut at the Venice Biennale.

abstract: The giant insurer is facing lawsuits from customers, agents and former employees accusing it of racial discrimination.

title: Marin Hinkle of ‘The Marvelous Mrs. Maisel’ Melts Chocolate
abstract: The television actress, who is filming the show’s fifth and final season, learned to make truffles.

abstract: Francis has raised his voice against “unacceptable armed aggression” without mentioning President Vladimir V. Putin or Russia. Some analysts say that he risks complicating his legacy.

title: How Oni and Uché Blackstock, Doctors, Spend Their Sundays
abstract: The twin sisters, who have been go-to experts during the pandemic, are outspoken on racial inequities in health care.

abstract: Some hopeful homeowners are keeping their rentals in pricey, urban areas, but are buying second homes in more affordable, rural and suburban locations.

title: Dispatch From Hungary: The Man Trying to Return His Country to the Free World
abstract: The strongman’s ties to Putin might finally hurt him.

byline: By Michael Barbaro, Michael Simon Johnson, Eric Krupke, Kaitlin Roberts, Patricia Willens, Marc Georges, Paige Cowett, Chris Wood and Marion Lozano
title: The Global Race to Mine the Metal of the Future
abstract: The quest for cobalt, which is essential for electric-car batteries, has fueled a cycle of exploitation, greed and gamesmanship.

title: America Has a Free Speech Problem
abstract: A new poll finds Americans very anxious about the state of free speech.

title: Covid and the ‘Very Liberal’
abstract: There’s a schism among Democrats. And the latest on Ukraine.

title: Pete Davidson No Longer Going to Space, Blue Origin Says
abstract: According to the company, the comedian is “no longer able to join” its coming mission. It was unclear whether another celebrity would take his seat.

title: The First Designated Hitter Is Ready for the Universal D.H.
abstract: Ron Blomberg was a curiosity when he took the pitcher’s spot in the batting order in 1973. Now it will be standard practice in both leagues. “They should have done this a long time ago.”

byline: By Ligaya Mishan, Anthony Cotsifas and Victoria Petro-Conroy
title: In a Starving World, Is Eating Well Unethical?
abstract: A meditation on the true cost of dining when nearly one-third of the planet lacks regular access to food.

byline: By Mike Ives and Makiko Inoue
title: A ‘Killing Stone’ Broke in Japan. Is a Demon on the Loose?
abstract: The rock appears in a famous legend starring a nine-tailed fox spirit. The question now is whether the fracture was a good or bad omen.

title: NASA’s Giant Moon Rocket Reaches the Launchpad for the First Time
abstract: NASA rolled the giant Space Launch System rocket out of an assembly building to begin testing ahead of its journey later this year toward the moon.

title: People shrug over flu. Will they soon be shrugging about Covid?
abstract: In good years, flu kills Americans in the low tens of thousands and sickens many times more. Yet even in the time of Covid, flu, the other respiratory killer caused by a virus, is underestimated. Almost half of American adults don’t bother to get vaccinated against it. Despite the ongoing Covid experience, researchers and historians don’t expect Americans’ attitudes toward flu to change much.

byline: By Andrew Ross Sorkin, Jason Karaian, Stephen Gandel, Michael J. de la Merced and Ephrat Livni
title: Is the Nickel Market Broken?
abstract: The chaos in trading of the metal could have broad implications.

byline: By Ronan Mckenzie and Eric McNeal
title: Easygoing Clothes in Shades of Cream and Khaki
abstract: Cocooning knits and enveloping jackets in neutral hues perfect for spring.

title: How one energy company C.E.O. is trying to keep the lights on in Ukraine.
abstract: DTEK, a prominent Ukrainian power company, arranges for soldiers to escort its emergency repair crews to reach damaged transmission lines.

title: Bringing Personal Finance to the Classroom for Generation Z
abstract: Twenty-three states require high schoolers to take the subject, and more could join them in an effort to boost the next generation’s financial literacy.

title: ‘American Song Contest’ Puts a Stateside Spin on Eurovision
abstract: Stars vs. hopefuls. State vs. state. Eurovision fans will recognize the format of NBC’s new original song competition. For everyone else, here’s a primer.

title: Love Letters to California
abstract: The state might be drought-stricken, fire-ridden and wildly expensive, but our readers love it all the same.

abstract: The Florida bill limits what educators can say about gender and sexuality, and could affect mental health services for all students.

abstract: Mbappé is a generational talent who deserves a bigger stage on a weekly basis than the one Paris St.-Germain can offer.

abstract: Tugan Sokhiev, who resigned from two posts after facing pressure to condemn the invasion of Ukraine, will not perform with the orchestra because of the war.

title: What Happened to One of Classical Music’s Most Popular Pieces?

abstract: We review Whitman College’s financial aid guarantee and Muhlenberg College’s refreshing explainer.

abstract: Ti West is the rare genre director to understand the original and honor it with a movie, “X,” that also works on its own terms.

title: Transcript: Ezra Klein Interviews Emma Ashford
abstract: A conversation with foreign policy scholar Emma Ashford.

byline: By Megan Specia and Josh Holder
title: Russia’s military progress slows, but it makes gains in the south and east.
abstract: Britain’s defense intelligence service said that Russian forces had “made minimal progress this week.”

title: Recommended Reading
abstract: “500 Books You’re a Fool for Not Having Read Already” and more.

title: Who Should Get a 4th Covid Shot?
abstract: Experts say that the most vulnerable would benefit from a second booster soonest.

title: What to Cook This Weekend
abstract: Eric Kim’s recipe for milk bread will provide ham and mayonnaise sandwiches (and more) for days.

abstract: This month’s picks include near-future psychological drama, Oscar-nominated robot antics and a bearded, mysterious Hugo Weaving.

abstract: The digital confrontation is playing out in the shadows, as inconspicuous as it is insidious.

title: Asian Americans Have Always Lived With Fear
abstract: In my decades growing up in New York, survival required constant vigilance. Sadly, very little has changed.

title: Transgender Youths Become a Political Issue in Texas
abstract: The transgender youth controversy in Texas; the “Don’t Say Gay” bill in Florida; U.S. policy and North Korea.

byline: By Emma Goldberg and Lananh Nguyen
title: As Offices Open and Mask Mandates Drop, Some Anxieties Set In
abstract: Using local guidelines, many companies are loosening Covid safety rules, leaving workers to navigate masking and social distancing on their own.

title: Hong Kong surpasses 1 million coronavirus cases, health officials say, amid a huge surge in deaths.
abstract: Once viewed as a world leader in controlling the coronavirus crisis, Hong Kong now has a death rate far outstripping that of mainland China.

title: Climate change is making armed conflict worse. Here’s how.

abstract: A survivor of a crippling accident, his documentaries and news coverage for public television focused on poverty, race and other social issues.

byline: By Jon Pareles, Giovanni Russonello and Lindsay Zoladz
title: Arcade Fire Ignites a Fresh Era, and 11 More New Songs
abstract: Hear tracks by Normani, Brad Mehldau, Valerie June and others.

abstract: Meticulous in building relationships, she helped open new markets for the cosmetics company, notably in the Soviet Union, as head of its international operations.

abstract: The superstar conductor, a possible successor to the New York Philharmonic’s podium, led a cycle of Robert Schumann’s symphonies and two premieres.

abstract: The latest edition of the DSM-5, sometimes known as “psychiatry’s bible,” includes a controversial new diagnosis: prolonged grief disorder.

abstract: When an age difference pulls a couple in different directions.

abstract: Ali Slagle takes the classic dish and gives it a 2022 update with chickpeas and kale.

abstract: The Iraq war showed us how dangerous policy driven by moral imperatives can be.

abstract: Sara Manning Peskin talks about “A Molecule Away From Madness,” and J. Kenji López-Alt discusses “The Wok.”

title: As diplomacy drags on, peace seems far off in Ukraine.

abstract: In Sam Chanse’s affecting play, a daughter tries to understand her mother, who resists any reminder of her escape from the Khmer Rouge.

abstract: Sheila Bridges’s Harlem Toile de Jouy wallpaper and designs are getting even more attention. For this writer, it fills in the visual gaps of Black tradition.

title: A Big Swing at Big Tech

title: Stephen Wilhite, creator of the animated GIF, has died of Covid complications.
abstract: Stephen E. Wilhite, a computer programmer who was best known for inventing the GIF, the looping animations that became a universal language for conveying humor, sarcasm and angst on social media and in instant messages, died in Cincinnati on March 14. He was 74.

title: Should I worry about any side effects?
abstract: Most people who take Paxlovid don’t experience serious side effects, though some may have diarrhea, muscle pain or an altered sense of taste. These, coincidentally, can also be symptoms of Covid-19, Dr. Luetkemeyer said.

title: How do I get antiviral pills for Covid-19?
abstract: First, you must test positive with a P.C.R. or rapid test. This can be done at home, at a regular health care provider’s office, at a testing site or at one of the pharmacy chains, community health centers, long-term-care facilities or Veterans Affairs clinics participating in the “test to treat” program.

title: Who is eligible for antiviral pills?
abstract: Not everyone who tests positive for Covid-19 will get a prescription for antiviral pills, said Dr. Annie Luetkemeyer, a professor of infectious diseases at the University of California, San Francisco. To be eligible, you must test positive and have symptoms that started within five days or fewer. You must also be at increased risk of developing severe Covid-19.

title: How effective are Covid antivirals?
abstract: Both Paxlovid and molnupiravir have been shown to reduce hospitalization and death from Covid-19 if taken early on in the course of an infection. “They are most effective when used within a few days of the onset of symptoms,” Dr. Gandhi said.

title: What antiviral treatments are available for Covid-19?
abstract: There are two oral antiviral therapies currently available to treat Covid-19 in the United States.

title: What are antiviral drugs and how do they work?
abstract: Antiviral medications have been around since the 1960s in the form of pills, intravenous solutions, ointments and even eye drops. They exist for only a handful of viruses, including H.I.V., the herpes simplex viruses, hepatitis B and C viruses, influenza A and B, and now the coronavirus.

byline: By Brian Finucane and Olga Oliker
title: Zelensky Wants a No-Fly Zone. NATO Is Right to Say No.

abstract: New data on teen mental health during the pandemic suggests that for many, home life was full of stressors like job loss, hunger and even violence.

title: Hugs to Boring
abstract: Don’t underestimate the tech that makes your eyes glaze over. It holds us all up.

title: Review: In ‘I Agree to the Terms,’ It’s Raining Pennies From Amazon
abstract: The Builders Association explores the world of turkers, workers performing thousands of weird, low-paying tasks for an online giant.

title: What Students Are Saying About How Social Media Affects Their Body Image
abstract: A recent article put a spotlight on how social media can fuel body dysmorphia in boys. We asked teenagers how these apps make them feel about the way they look.
